Fun fact: The beavers' dams are built not just for shelter, but also to store caches of food for the winter.

Habitat: Well-covered areas such as forests or swamps
Diet: Small mammals, fish, insects, nuts, berries, etc.
Fun fact: An adult black bear will sometimes travel as far as 95 miles in a year, marking trees with their claws as they go.
Big brown bats can eat up to one third their body weight in insects on a single night.

Habitat: Forests, mountains, other areas with rugged terrain
Fun fact: It's rare, but not impossible, for a bobcat to kill and eat large animals such as livestock.

Diet: Small animals in winter/spring; insects and fruit in summer/fall
Fun fact: Gray foxes are adept climbers and will use trees in order to escape enemies.
A deer mouse's tail makes up more than half of its entire length and features a pencil-shaped tip.

Diet: Just about anything - mammals, insects, fruits, etc.
Fun fact: Coyotes are opportunistic feeders and can adapt to many different kinds of environment.
Eastern chipmunks hibernate through the cold season, going underground in mid-November and emerging early February.
Gray squirrels have many different calls to communicate and can live for up to 6 years In the wild.
Raccoons are highly intelligent animals and can remember solutions to tasks for at least three years.

Diet: Fish and other small aquatic animals
Fun fact: An otter's den will have multiple tunnel openings and allow access to both land and water.

Diet: Mostly rabbits and mice, plus fruits and insects
Fun fact: Red foxes will occasionally capture moles and give them to their pups as playthings.
Southern flying squirrels can find their way back to their nests from up to a kilometer away.
Striped skunks use a powerful, smelly spray from scent glands to defend themselves. The glands then take two weeks to refill.
Opossums are famous for "playing possum", i.e. playing dead in order to deter predators.
When white-tailed deer run away from danger, the visible white of their tails acts as an alert to other deer.
You wouldn't know it from looking at them, but woodchucks/groundhogs are actually excellent swimmers and decent climbers.
Their name comes from the deep, bull-like call that they make during breeding season.

Diet: Insects, beetles, anything they can swallow
Fun fact: During breeding season, groups of males often "bark" together in unison.
Cope's gray treefrogs are highly freeze tolerant, able to survive temperatures as low as 18°F (-8 °C).
One American toad can eat up to 1,000 insects every day.
An Eastern cricket frog can leap up to 3 feet in a single jump to evade predators.
Don't touch your face after handling one - their skin secretion causes a violent burning sensation in the eyes.

Habitat: Forests and other areas with loose soil
Fun fact: Their name comes from the spade-shaped appendages protruding from their hind feet, which are useful for burrowing.
The male Fowler's toad's mating call happens to also attract other males. Males also have a special "release call" for when another male tries to mate by mistake.
During mating season, males will eavesdrop on each other's mating calls in order to get a head start on approaching females.
Gray treefrogs will sometimes congregate around windows and porch lights, a perfect place to catch bugs attracted to the glow.
This species mates nearly year-round, breeding in all months except September.
Their skin secretions are lethal to other frogs and predators, making this the only poisonous frog species native to the United States.
This species is able to navigate during migration using the moon and stellar patterns.
The Latin name, "crucifer", means "cross-bearing" and refers to the cross-shaped pattern on its back.
Mothers of this species will wrap their bodies around their egg cluster, collecting a pool of water for the eggs to hatch in.

Diet: Insects, crustaceans, young amphibians, frog eggs
Fun fact: Their bright coloring serves as a warning to predators of the poisonous tetrodotoxin secreted through their skin.
These salamanders have a long lifespan, with many living for 20 years and some even living for 30.
When threatened, they respond by curling up their body, tucking their head, and waving their tail.
This species of salamander is unique in that it lays its eggs on land, skipping the typical aquatic larval stage that most amphibians share.
When caught by a predator, a skink is able to disconnect its entire tail in order to escape.
During mating season, females will emit a pheromone from their tail that males can track by flicking their tongue.
These lizards exhibit a behavior called "jiggling" - a short series of head bobs that generally indicates arousal.
They're shy and extremely quick - able to dart away at speeds up to 18 mph (29 kmh).

Diet: Cicadas, caterpillars, lizards, voles, mice, etc.
Fun fact: This snake can vibrate its tail more than 40 times a second, more than almost any other non-rattlesnake species.
Juveniles can strike at predators with so much force that their entire body leaves the ground.

Habitat: Forests and fields with sandy soil
Fun fact: Generally docile, this snake will elaborately feign its own death if provoked.
You read the Diet section correctly - these snakes are known for hunting and killing other snakes, including venemous ones.
The most commonly-observed snake in Virginia. They are often seen climbing trees to get to bird nests.
Often killed by humans misidentifying it as a cottonmouth; these have a thin body and round pupils, whereas they have a fat body and cat-like pupils.

Habitat: Forests and wooded habitats with soft soil
Fun fact: When held, this snake will attempt to "burrow" between your fingers.

Diet: Insects, lizards, frogs, other snakes, small mammals, etc.
Fun fact: Despite the word "constrictor" in their Latin name, these snakes kill prey by pinning them down and swallowing them alive.
Instead of biting, these snakes release foul-smelling feces when caught.
At night, these snakes are found sleeping coiled in the branches of trees.
These snakes are seldom seen, often using rodent burrows and tree roots for shelter.
Also called "stinkpots", these turtles discharge a foul-smelling odor when disturbed.
A two-headed Eastern Painted Turtle was fonud in Chesterfield County in 1973.
The shape of the Eastern River Cooter's nasal area allows it to breathe while totally submerged.

Diet: Insects, fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, small mammals
Fun fact: Despite the popular conception, common snapping turtles are actually quite docile and prefer to avoid confrontation.

Diet: Insects, snails, crustaceans, frogs, aquatic plants
Fun fact: These turtles hide in substrate or mulkrat burrows over the winter.

Diet: Worms, snails, insects, fruit, berries, etc.
Fun fact: In captivity, box turtles have been known to live for over 100 years.

Diet: Fish; sometimes amphibians, reptiles, small mammals
Fun fact: They have excellent photoreceptors, allowing them to hunt at nighttime.
Their large wings, flapping twice per second, can propel them at around 25 mph (40 kmh).
These herons don't mind human company and can often be found nesting on neighborhood rooftops.

Habitat: Coastal and inland wetlands, ponds, lakes
Diet: Fish; sometimes frogs, aquatic insects, worms, rodents
Fun fact: Green Herons can actually use tools, turning bread crusts and insects into fishing lures.
Mother cormorants will collect water in their mouths to bring home to their chicks.
Their wings beat over 50 times per second.
They feed by searching the ground for seeds, typically collecting them in a pocket of the esophagus to be eaten later.
One of the few bird species that can use their beaks as a straw to drink water.
Famous for their migration patterns, Canada geese sometimes fly as far as 900 miles (1500 km) northward to molt.
A rare duck species with strong claws, mainly used to grip and perch on tree branches.
The comb-like nature of their bills allows them to scoop water and filter out crustaceans and seeds to eat.
Only female mallards quack loudly; males just make a small rasping sound.

Diet: Fish, aquatic plants and insects, crayfish, amphibians
Fun fact: They can see underwater to hunt; their eyes can refract light differently underwater, and they have an extra set of clear goggle-like eyelids.
They can fly up to 69 mph (112 km/h) when hunting prey.
One of the smallest birds of prey; they themselves are also prey for larger hawks and owls.
Known for their distinctive "pee-a-weee!" song, which they sing at all times of day.
They bathe by rubbing their body against dewy plants in the morning.
Highly intelligent birds, they have been known to mimic the call of the Red-Shouldered Hawk as either a warning or a deception tactic.
Noted for their intelligence; studies have shown that they can remember people and identify them based on appearance.
They are territorial in the winter, living in flocks of 2-8 and defending their areas against other flocks.
Known to incorporate animal hair into their nests, sourced from living animals such as squirrels, raccoons, and even humans.
In the evening time, hundreds of thousands of tree swallows will sometimes converge into a giant swirling flock in the sky.
Able to eat flying insects at more than 500 feet from the ground.
Known to hoard seeds for the winter by stuffing them into gaps in tree bark.
Their bills are specially shaped for picking apart loose tree bark.
For their small size, they produce a startlingly loud song.

Diet: Insects in summer, fruit in winter
Fun fact: Male bluebirds will bring material to make a nest, but females are typically responsible for building the nest and tending to the eggs.
A study has suggested that robins will choose to eat bug-infested fruit in order to round out their diet.
If a waxwing eats enough honeysuckle berries while growing a tail feather, it will grow out orange instead of the usual yellow.
In order to lure predators away from the nest, a warbler will perform a "broken wing display", pretending to be injured and therefore an easy meal.
Fiercely territorial, cardinals may be seen attacking their reflection in windows and mirrors during springtime.
These birds actually have no blue pigment; instead, tiny structures in their feathers reflect blue light. They appear dark brown when not lit.
Brown-headed Cowbirds sometimes insert their own eggs into Scarlet Tanager nests; the tanagers will raise the cowbird as one of their own.

Diet: Bees, wasps; sometimes other insects, fruit
Fun fact: Before eating a bee or wasp, a Summer Tanager will rub its body against a branch to remove the stinger.

Diet: Insects in summer, fruit in winter
Fun fact: Mockingbirds mimic the sounds of other birds; a male mockingbird can learn up to 200 different songs.
These birds time their egg hatching to occur before a full moon; during this time, they can hunt at night to better feed their little ones.
Originally from Mexico, this prized game bird's rich flavor comes from its wild nutty diet.
Hunting and agriculture have reduced Bobwhite population by 81% since the 1960s. They are now an important target for conservation efforts.
The Turkey Vulture's keen sense of smell allows it to locate carrion from far away, even from above a forest canopy.
Lacking a strong sense of smell, they mostly find carrion by following and overpowering the Turkey Vultures.
These particular hawks are specially-evolved to hunt fish; their reversible outer toes are perfect for gripping wet scales.

Diet: Rabbits, squirrels, and other small mammals; sometimes larger ones
Fun fact: Famed hunters, these eagles have even been seen fighting off bears and coyotes.

Diet: Fish; sometimes birds, reptiles, amphibians, crabs, mammals
Fun fact: Their association with American integrity is a bit ironic - Bald Eagles often steal their meals from ospreys and fish-eating mammals.
Males show off to females through a "sky dance" - calling while soaring and diving repeatedly through the air.

Habitat: Fields, grasslands, desert, scrub, parks, etc
Fun fact: If you've ever heard a magestic eagle scream in a movie or TV show, you've actually heard the call of the Red-Tailed Hawk.
Owls swallow their prey whole, then cough up "pellets" of skin, bones, and other undigestible material.

Diet: Small mammals, birds, insects, worms, amphibians, reptiles
Fun fact: These owls dive for prey in a classic U shape: straight down, forward, straight up.

Diet: A large variety of mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, etc
Fun fact: A Great Horned Owl's hearing is amplified by facial disc feathers that catch sound and direct it to the ears.

Diet: A large variety of mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, etc
Fun fact: This owl has a very recognizable call; it sounds like "who cooks for you? Who cooks for you?"
These smaller owls will typically make two separate meals out of a single mouse.
Sapsuckers get their sap by tapping holes into maple trees, very similarly to how we humans collect maple syrup.
Their sticky, barbed tongue extends almost 2 inches past the end of their beak.
Drumming against a tree isn't actually part of woodpeckers' feeding behavior; instead, it's their version of singing.

Habitat: Forest edges, fields, parks, suburban areas
Fun fact: Instead of hammering on trees, this particular woodpecker prefers to use its long tongue to eat ants off the ground.

Diet: Carpenter ants; sometimes other ants, insects, fruit, nuts
Fun fact: These large woodpeckers can create holes large enough to break small trees in half.

Habitat: Forests, burned areas, swamps, parks, roadsides
Fun fact: They are known to store food - sometimes including live trapped insects - in cracks in wood and bark.
Labeled a "Predatory and Undesirable Species" in Virginia due to its aggresive nature and ability to outcompete Largemouth and Smallmouth bass.

Habitat: Anadromous (lives in saltwater, spawns in freshwater)
Diet: Zooplankton, shrimp; sometimes crustaceans, smaller fish
Fun fact: Their name is said to refer to a female tavernkeeper, or "ale-wife".

Habitat: Anadromous (lives in saltwater, spawns in freshwater)
Diet: Shrimp; sometimes smaller fish (juveniles eat zooplankton and insect larvae)
Fun fact: Known as "America's Founding Fish" due to their history as an important food source for Indigenous Peoples and early colonists.
They tend to lay their eggs near submerged structures such as tree stumps, brush, or boat docks.

Habitat: Freshwater, benthic (lays on the bottom of a body of water)
Fun fact: They are nocturnal, staying in dark holes in the riverbed during the day and emerging at night.

Habitat: Anadromous (lives in saltwater, spawns in freshwater)
Fun fact: These fish have sharp, spiny scales, or "scutes", along their underside.

Diet: Generalist - insects, crustaceans, worms, smaller fish
Fun fact: A type of sunfish, these fish will linger near the water's surface to stay warm in the sun.

Habitat: Freshwater, benthic (lays on the bottom of a body of water)
Diet: Omnivorous - crustaceans, smaller fish, amphibians; sometimes small mammals
Fun fact: These catfish have taste buds all over their body, particularly on their whisker-like "barbels".

Habitat: Freshwater, benthic (lays on the bottom of a body of water)
Diet: Omnivorous - worms, small crustaceans, fish eggs, mussels, seeds, insects
Fun fact: Carp feed by sifting through mud, consuming just about anything that comes up in the process.

Habitat: Freshwater, benthic (lays on the bottom of a body of water)
Diet: Smaller fish; juveniles feed on insects, crayfish
Fun fact: A female lays, on average, 100,000 eggs in a clutch.
This fish does in fact have a "gizzard", an organ that helps it grind and break down food.
True to its name, the Largemouth Bass can open its mouth wider than its head.
This tiny fish features an "eye spot" that fools predators into thinking it's a much larger fish.
A special set of teeth enables them to crunch snail shells, hence the local nickname "shallcrackers".

Diet: Smaller fish, crayfish, amphibians; sometimes small mammals
Fun fact: These fish are extremely popular among anglers for their ability to put up a serious fight when hooked.

Habitat: Anadromous (lives in saltwater, spawns in freshwater)
Diet: Smaller fish, particularly shad, alewife and herring
Fun fact: The largest Striped Bass ever recorded was caught in 1896 and weighed a whopping 124 pounds (56 kg).

Diet: Smaller fish, crayfish, amphibians, insects, etc.
Fun fact: Their name comes from their eyes, which are opaque in appearance thanks to a layer of tissue called "tapetum lucidum" that enhances low-light vision.

Habitat: Anadromous (lives in saltwater, spawns in freshwater)
Diet: Smaller fish, crustaceans, insects, worms, plants, etc.
Fun fact: A female can lay over 150,000 eggs in a clutch; often, multiple males will work to fertilize them all.

Diet: Smaller fish, crustaceans; juveniles feed on zooplankton
Fun fact: Their eggs are laid in jelly-like strands that get draped around submerged structures or weeds.
A bee hive may have as many as 50,000 individual bees living inside.
The first-ever known drawing of a butterfly in North America was of an eastern tiger swallowtail, drawn by John White in 1587 during a Virginia expedition. It's now the state insect of Virginia.

Diet: Fruit, sap; larvae eat rotting wood
Fun fact: This beetle can supposedly lift and carry up to 850 times its own body weight.
It's unknown why moths circle around artificial lights; one hypothesis is that they mistake them for the moon and try to navigate against them.
